Award.AwardTitle: Conference: A Broad Perspective on Finite and Infinite Dimensional Dynamical Systems'
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "A Broad Perspective on Finite and Infinite Dimensional Dynamical Systems" will be held in Barcelona, Spain, June 12-16, 2017. The event aims to serve as a launching pad for advancing the frontiers of research, and for promoting international collaborations between scientists from the USA and abroad. The NSF award will defray the travel expenses of attending the conference for PhD students, young researchers, and participants from the USA with no current NSF support, including members of under-represented groups.

At the core of this conference stands the interdisciplinary approach to fundamental problems at the interface of finite and infinite dynamical systems, partial differential equations, and geometry. This approach has lead in the recent years to the development of innovative methodologies, including computational tools, that are relevant to working scientists in different fields, such as molecular biology, particle accelerators, plasma confinement, condensed matter, geophysical fluid dynamics, astrodynamics, and astrophysics. The conference will showcase and disseminate recent progress in the field, unfold innovative ideas, and jump-start new research projects. Additional information on this conference can be found at http://www.crm.cat/en/Activities/Curs_2016-2017/Pages/C_FIDDS.aspx

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions between dynamical systems, partial differential equations, and geometry are at the core of numerous applications to sciences and technology, such as those related to chemical reactions, molecular dynamics, particle accelerators, plasma confinement, condensed matter, geophysical fluid dynamics, spacecraft dynamics and mission analysis. The main activity supported by this grant was the conference “A Broad Perspective on Finite and Infinite Dimensional Dynamical Systems”, June 12-16, 2017, Barcelona. This event served as an international forum for scientists in the aforementioned fields, where novel ideas have been presented, existing challenges have been tackled, and plans for future developments have been mapped out.

The conference turned out to be a major scientific success. It was attended by 149 participants from all over the world, including US, Spain, Netherlands, Italy, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, France, Denmark, Greece, Finland, Poland, UK, Russia, Israel, China, Mexico, Brazil, and Australia. At the conference there were presented 28 main talks, 20 contributed talks, and 28 posters.  Among the participants there were many graduate students and young researchers; there were 120 men, and 29 women.

In particular, this grant provided partial support for 21 US participants, including 13 graduate students, 2 postdocs, 2 young faculty, and 4 other faculty without current support; these participants included 4 women and 4 Hispanics.

The main outcomes of the conference were: (1) Advancement of the capacity for discovery through expanding the current approaches, and development of new methodologies, (2) Strengthening existing interdisciplinary research groups and building new ones, (3) Fostering international collaboration between research teams in USA, Europe, and elsewhere, (4) Contributing to the education and training of US graduate students and young researchers, while encouraging the participation of under-represented groups. 

New research resulting from the participation to this conference are going to be disseminated through a Special Issue of Discrete and Continuous Dynamical Systems - Series A (Eds. Amadeu Delshams, Xavier Cabre, Marian Gidea and Chongchun Zeng); this special issue in currently under preparation.  In the long run, new results will emerge as a result of participation to this conference, including from collaborations among participants. These will be published in professional journals in the field of dynamical systems and related fields.
